text: {"grade": 0, "reasoning": "The criterion requires the response to identify Article II of the New York Convention as relevant to resisting judicial interference. The candidate answer focuses almost entirely on Article V defenses (lack of jurisdiction, due process) and general pro-enforcement principles, citing cases like Mitsubishi and First Options. It does not explicitly mention or identify Article II (which deals with the recognition and enforcement of written arbitration agreements, often used to compel arbitration or resist judicial proceedings that interfere with the agreement) as a relevant argument for resisting enforcement based on the existence of the agreement itself, which is what the criterion asks for in the context of resisting judicial interference (like an injunction).", "criterion_id": "8ff30d78-acbb-408c-9669-f016cc43474e"}
